abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. Lessons are addressed under three
            categories: underlying theory and assumptions; project
            design; and, project implementation. First, the reasoning
            behind most water supply, and sanitation projects is that
            water is a public good with impact on health, whereas
            sanitation is considered a private good. Though not
            explicit, this implies that while water supply should be
            subsidized (or publicly intervened), sanitation remain a
            personal decision matter, thus the project actively
            challenged sanitary integration through the inclusion of a
            hygiene and sanitation education component, stimulating a
            household package for latrine construction. Second,
            operations like this one, should use simple project design
            schemes, relying on community participation, through proper
            training, and technical support; but, accountability for
            funds allocation, should be centrally channeled,
            particularly if inter-governmental coordination is
            politically, or technically weak. It is emphasized that
            reliable, and timely data collection is required for a
            continuous hands-on operation, and corrective changes,
            avoiding comparable data which may be hindered by variable
            methods. Third, project implementation should consider both
            political, and logistic criteria; ensure monitoring and
            evaluation; and, balance institutional arrangements between
            limited cost overruns, and procedures.
